thread.title: Nicole Kidman’s new series Big Little Lies a ratings hit for Foxtel
thread.title_full: Nicole Kidman’s new series Big Little Lies a ratings hit for Foxtel

author: Holly Byrnes
title: Nicole Kidman’s new series Big Little Lies a ratings hit for Foxtel
text:
IT’S been dubbed ‘Mean Girls for adults’ but there was a whole lot of love for Nicole Kidman’s TV return in Big Little Lies yesterday — with the dark dramedy pulling the second largest audience for an HBO series on debut. 
The sophisticated suburbia tale , which follows the secrets and lives of a circle of wealthy women from a coastal town in California, was watched by more than 133,000 viewers across its launch broadcasts (44,000 viewers at 1pm, then 89,000 viewers for the prime-time encore).
It’s a solid start for the subscription service, second only to the wildly popular Walking Dead series which has established its loyal audience over seven seasons.
It marks the second largest HBO series launch of all time for Foxtel only trailing the 2016 public holiday debut of the Golden Globe-nominated drama hit Westworld (141,000 viewers).
To broaden the drama’s reach, Foxtel will offer the first episode for free on its website www.foxtel.com.au for the next 30 days.
Big Little Lies has been dubbed ‘Mean Girls’ for adults. Source: Foxtel 
Meanwhile, the free-to-air battle remains tight between Seven’s dominant My Kitchen Rules cooking contest and Nine’s social experiment, Married At First Sight .
MKR held on to win the night against its new reality rival, 1.363 million viewers to MAFS ’s 1.096 million.
Adrian Swift, Nine’s head of content, production and development, was celebrating the rise across all free-to-air programming on Monday night, arguing the competition was healthy and the audience the real winner.
“For the first time in a long time, we have been taking on Seven and we’ve got a show everyone’s talking about,” Mr Swift said.
“The difference between I’m A Celebrity ... Get Me Out Of Here! and MKR is that our show is real. We never know what’s going to happen next. And viewers love that.”
